newsitem.title: UK: Sugar freight activity eases, thin inquiry.
newsitem.headline: Sugar freight activity eases, thin inquiry.

text.p: Business slackened off on the sugar freight market on Wednesday with only one fixture and one new inquiry reported, both from north Brazil, shipbrokers said.

Jean Lion fixed 14,000 tonnes of bulk sugar to Syria with various options for prompt shipment dates and Genoc quoted for 6/8,000 tonnes of bagged sugar from the same origin to Algeria, Syria or Turkey, they said.
Elsewhere, Australia's Queensland Sugar Corporation said it would supply the first raw sugar ever imported by Saudi Arabia in a new 55,000-tonne deal.
QSC said the sugar would be shipped in two cargoes to the new refinery in Jeddah, epxpected to begin production in early 1997. The first cargo is due to leave Bundaberg on November 21
Thai sugar exports rose 17.8 percent in the first 10 months of 1996 to 4.29 million tonnes, against 3.64 million tonnes in the same period last year.
Japan remained the biggest buyer so far this year, foloowed by Indonesia. There have been no deliveries to China, the biggest buyer of Thai sugar last year, since August.
